title: Incest, patricide, cold-blooded murder: remembering Profit, the drama too dark for TV
text:
In 1996, inspired by Richard III, two TV writers created the most pitch-black series ever seen on US screens. Rupert Murdoch loved it; viewers were repulsed. But was Profit ahead of its time?

Jessie Pinkman rolling back into town for the forthcoming Breaking Bad movie El Camino is a reminder of how dark we like our entertainment these days. Indeed, the modern history of American television has been drawn largely by characters of dubious morality. Pinkman’s mentor Walter White masterminded a drugs empire. Tony Soprano had men whacked. And The Shield’s hardcase cop Vic Mackay was up to his eyeballs in corruption.
